Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 01:23PM akmom wrote: Hi purple32 I think MarieKelly is referring to surgical removal of tissues that would have been in contact with the instrument that removed the biopsy sample - the "track" along which the biopsied cells travelled on the way out. You may find the following thread helpful: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/111/topic/752083?page=2#idx_31
Posts.Title: LEFT BREAST RADS. SE? purple32 purple32

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2011 12:49PM akmom wrote: Hi Dawn I had a mammogram on Sep 7.  They found a cluster of microcalcifications so I was referred for an ultrasound, which was done on Sep 15.  Had an appointment with my family doctor to follow up on Sep 23, after which his office contacted the hospital to make an appointment for a stereotactic core biopsy (radiologist's recommendation).  I had to wait a long time just for a call back, but finally was told that my biopsy would be on Nov 29.  Had the biopsy as scheduled, got a call from my family doctor Dec 5 to say that they have my results and I need to come in for a "non-urgent" follow up. I made an appointment for Dec 9 (probably could have got an earlier date but I figure the "non-urgent" is a good sign). So it will be 3 months from my mammogram to getting the biopsy results. The nurse at my biopsy asked if I had been waiting long; apparently they have been working overtime trying to get rid of a backlog.  I am in Canada, by the way, where surgery wait lists are not unusual, at least for non-emergency conditions.  The Bi-rads score on my mammo was a 4.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 11:01PM akmom wrote: Skapaya, I had a mammogram-assisted core biopsy (rather than ultrasound). Experience was very much like Blessings and Sandi, except for my breast being squished between the plates. But there didn't seem to be as much pressure as with a regular mammogram (luckily). The reason I had a core biopsy is that the mammogram showed a pattern of microcalcifications, rather than one specific lump or cyst. So I guess they wanted samples from different parts of the area of concern. I've also had a fine needle biopsy in the past, and that was for a distinct lump rather than the calcifications. It wasn't painful, and the medical folks know exactly what they're doing and will put you at ease. Try not to worry :) easier said than done, I know!

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 06:35PM akmom wrote: Just back from the Breast Health Clinic. The surgeon doesn't think an excisional biopsy is necessary, hurray! Just a follow up mammo in six months. It was hard to worm information out of the doc - he just said "good news, you don't have cancer" and I think he was ready to leave it at that. I had to ask what it meant that they found atypical cells, and then ask again whether there was hyperplasia (he almost rolled his eyes when I used that term - I could tell he was thinking, sheesh, another one diagnosing herself on the internet). He also let slip the word "ductal" so I put the three together for a do-it-yourself diagnosis of Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia. He did say I had a slightly higher risk of bc because of my family history (father's mom & sister having bc and father prostate cancer increased odds from the usual 1 in 9 to 1 in 7). I asked what the chances are that the core biopsy might have missed an area of concern, and he said 1 in 18,000 (good odds if you're buying a lottery ticket but not too alarming in this sense). Then he did a physical exam and found a thickening in the other breast, sent me right away for an ultrasound and based on that decided it's just a simple cyst. Glad I was at the Clinic so they could get it done immediately, what a relief. I am so, so, grateful for the support and info on these boards, which made it easier for me to get through the last few months. Thanks so much to my new "breast friends" :) No doubt I'll be back in a few months, in the meantime I wish good outcomes and good health to all. Dale
Posts.Title: So who is waiting for test results/ or having test Tenmom Kimberly5307

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 01:15AM akmom wrote: I'm back in the waiting room :) After a core biopsy in December I was told that atypical cells and hyperplasia were noted by the hospital pathologist, get another mammo in six months. In January I got a phone call from another surgeon at the breast health clinic to say that following a review by "her" pathologist, low grade DCIS is suspected. Had excisional biopsy Feb 13, appointment made for Feb 24 to hear the verdict. Hope the results are conclusive, either way... I hate being in limbo.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2012 04:01PM akmom wrote: Kaytre, it's true my mammogram was way back in September, and the results were immediately identified as suspicious. The delay is due to the lengthy waits for each procedure. Waited for an ultrasound, waited for a follow up with my PCP, waited for an appointment for the core biopsy, waited to see a breast surgeon for the results, had a second surgeon get in on the discussion (thank goodness she did), waited for an excisional biopsy, and then waited to hear the results, which brings us to today. Now I am waiting to see the cancer folks regarding radiation, and if that's necessary, I'll be waiting to be scheduled for treatment. One of the joys of living in Canada - medical care doesn't cost anything, but sometimes it takes a while to get what you need.
Posts.Title: So who is waiting for test results/ or having test Tenmom Kimberly5307

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2018 10:27AM akmom wrote: Hi Diane, I had a simple double mastectomy on August 14, no reconstruction, no lymph node dissection. - I took nothing to hospital as I went home the same day - wear comfy clothes: pull-on pants and top that opens in front. Have a small pillow to put under seat belt for the ride home - I had very little pain post op, was on Tylenol 3 for only a day or two after op - At home I had a wedge pillow to prop up myself in bed (and an extra pillow for under my knees). It was very hard to sit up from a horizontal position at first. Start on a stool softener right away as General anaesthetic can cause constipation. If you have to cook for yourself have some easy food ready to heat up for a few days. Make sure items you will need are in easy reach (counter height). Also I couldn't open meds with child proof caps so plan ahead - ask pharmacy to use easy open lids for any prescriptions you will need. Although you may be okay having one “good” arm - special items: I had to buy pyjamas with front opening (couldn't lift arms to get tops over my head). One of those “grabber” things would have been helpful for reaching things down from shelves etc. Small pillow to tuck under your armpit for comfort. - my drains came out on day 6 post MX; you will need to be draining below a certain level for two consecutive days and this can be different for everyone. The drains aren't that big but there is all the tubing as well. I just wore my regular size (but was mostly in pyjamas!) with maybe a loose sweater over top From what I have read, it seems like reconstruction causes a lot of the complications- I had none and hope you will be the same! I did have quite a lot of swelling around the incisions, and under my arms especially, but it is finally starting to subside after six weeks. I am in Canada, not sure where you would buy mastectomy items in your area. There are some specialty retail outlets here that carry mastectomy items but so far I haven't bought anything. I wanted to get a camisole with pockets to hold the drains but couldn’t find anything (except online) and I didn't really need it after all. Used big safety pins to attach them to the garment that the hospital provided (like a stretchy “boob tube” with Velcro opening down the front). Ask your doc or call the hospital to find out if they provide something similar, maybe? Hope this helps, let me know if you have more questions. You will find lots of great info on this site and good support. There is almost always somebody who has “been there, done that” and can give you some insight. Good luck! When is your surgery date? Dale xx
Posts.Title: Advice On Preparing/Recovering From Mastectomy Diane500 Denise-G

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2012 03:54PM akmom wrote: Had my appointment for results and got a copy of my pathology report. A. Ductal carcinoma in situ: intermediate grade, size 3 mm, not present at specimen edges, lesion is 2 mm away from closest inked margin, no invasive carcinoma identified :) B. Florid fibrocystic change of the breast: columnar cell change present, florid foci of usual ductal hyperplasia, paillomatosis present, multiple radial scars present, apocrine change present. C. Previous biopsy site histologically identified: foreign body giant cell reaction present. My surgeon was pretty happy with the result, says it was very tiny and now it's gone; now she's sending me to the cancer agency to see if they recommend radiation. I told her that I was so grateful to her for perservering. If it had been left to the previous surgeon, I would have gone away and the cells would have had at least another six months to grow nastier. I will have to do some reading and see what it all means! Thanks everyone, for all the support during this waiting period. Now waiting to find out about radiation...

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 12:04AM akmom wrote: Welcome to the club nobody really wants to join, dlb. You'll hear this again and again, but the waiting really is the hardest part. I had a similar mammo to yours, clustered microcalcs, birad 4, had a core biopsy and then an excisional biopsy which hopefully got all of the DCIS (just a tiny bit and caught very early, thanks to the mammo). Sometimes it's hard to know what to ask the health professionals, and I have found this site so helpful in preparing for appointments and understanding the medical-speak. Not to mention the advice and moral support given by the members. So glad you have your family and friends close. Keep your chin up, the odds are on your side for a benign result. Will be thinking of you on the 6th. :)
